abstract_summ: Our data strongly support the hypothesis that in-utero vertical transmission is possible in SARS-CoV-2 positive pregnant women.Finally, a specific inflammatory response is triggered by SARS-CoV-2 infection in pregnant women at both systemic and placental level, and in umbilical cord blood plasma.To evaluate the effect of breastfeeding on SARS-CoV-2 transmission, the presence of SARS-CoV-2, IgG and IgM in breast milk, maternal blood and infant blood were assessed.Eight studies analyzing the presence of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in the breast milk of 24 pregnant women with COVID-19 during the third trimester of pregnancy were found.We obtained multiple maternal, placental and neonatal swabs, which showed a median viral load in maternal blood, urine, oropharynx, fornix posterior over a period of 6 days was 5.0 log copies /mL. The maternal side of the placenta had a viral load of 4.42 log copies /mL, while the fetal side had 7.15 log copies /mL. Maternal breast milk, feces and all neonatal samples tested negative.
title_summ: Evidence and possible mechanisms of rare maternal-fetal transmission of SARS-CoV-2.IN-UTERO MOTHER-TO-CHILD SARS-CoV-2 TRANSMISSION: viral detection and fetal immune responseSafety of Breastfeeding in Mothers with SARS-CoV-2 InfectionSARS-CoV-2 placental infection and inflammation leading to fetal distress and neonatal multi-organ failure in an asymptomatic womanTo breastfeed or not to breastfeed?Lack of evidence on the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in breastmilk of pregnant women with COVID-19Evidence for and against vertical transmission for SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19)Detection of SARS-COV-2 in Placental and Fetal Membrane SamplesDoes the maternal-fetal transmission of SARS-CoV-2 occur during pregnancy?()
title_abstract_phrases: Our data strongly support the hypothesis that in-utero vertical transmission is possible in SARS-CoV-2 positive pregnant women.Finally, a specific inflammatory response is triggered by SARS-CoV-2 infection in pregnant women at both systemic and placental level, and in umbilical cord blood plasma.Evidence and possible mechanisms of rare maternal-fetal transmission of SARS-CoV-2.While SARS-CoV-2 infection has spread rapidly worldwide, data remains scarce about the natural history of infection in pregnant women and the risk of mother-to-fetal transmission.To evaluate the effect of breastfeeding on SARS-CoV-2 transmission, the presence of SARS-CoV-2, IgG and IgM in breast milk, maternal blood and infant blood were assessed.Eight studies analyzing the presence of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in the breast milk of 24 pregnant women with COVID-19 during the third trimester of pregnancy were found.
